Certainly! Here are detailed explanations of each of the sub-points for Chapter Six, which covers the use of lexical semantics in analyzing word pairs and semantic contrasts:

6.1 Word Pairs and Antonymy

* This sub-point discusses the use of antonymy, or the relationship between words with opposite meanings, in biblical exegesis. It explains how analyzing antonyms can provide insights into the meaning of individual words and phrases, as well as the broader meaning of a text.

6.2 Word Pairs and Synonymy

* This sub-point discusses the use of synonymy, or the relationship between words with similar meanings, in biblical exegesis. It explains how analyzing synonyms can aid in understanding the meaning of individual words and phrases, and how the use of synonyms can provide insights into the rhetorical strategies employed by biblical authors.

6.3 Word Pairs and Complementation

* This sub-point discusses the use of complementation, or the relationship between words that are used together to convey a complete meaning, in biblical exegesis. It explains how analyzing complementation can aid in understanding the meaning of individual words and phrases, and how the use of complementation can provide insights into the broader meaning of a text.

6.4 Word Pairs and Metaphor

* This sub-point discusses the use of metaphor, or the use of words or phrases to represent something else, in biblical exegesis. It explains how analyzing metaphors can aid in understanding the meaning of individual words and phrases, and how the use of metaphors can provide insights into the broader meaning of a text.

6.5 Word Pairs and Irony

* This sub-point discusses the use of irony, or the use of words to convey the opposite of their literal meaning, in biblical exegesis. It explains how analyzing irony can aid in understanding the meaning of individual words and phrases, and how the use of irony can provide insights into the rhetorical strategies employed by biblical authors.

6.6 Word Pairs and Collocation

* This sub-point discusses the use of collocation, or the way in which words are commonly used together, in biblical exegesis. It explains how analyzing collocation can aid in understanding the meaning of individual words and phrases, and how the use of collocation can provide insights into the broader meaning of a text.
